DataElement.preferredName: Molecular Analysis Histone Gene Family Category
DataElement.preferredDefinition: The text term used to describe the family, or classification of a group of basic proteins found in chromatin, called histones.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A laboratory procedure that involves the study of tissues, cells, and fluids using DNA/RNA analysis techniques for the identification of characteristics and abnormalities at the molecular level._Major protein component of chromatin.  Highly conserved basic proteins, originally classified into classes based on the relative amounts of arginine and lysine in each protein.  The various classes are now termed H1, H2A, H2B, H3, and H4.  In chromatin, they are found in an octamer, containing two each of H2A, H2B, H3, and H4, complexed with DNA in nucleosomes.  The histones in the octamer complex are also known as the core histones.  The H1 class of histones, termed the linker histones, is loosely associated with the nucleosome._A set of genes coding for diverse proteins which, by virtue of their high degree of sequence similarity, are believed to have evolved from a single ancestral gene.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Techniques for studying or analyzing the genetic composition and mechanisms of living organisms at the molecular level. May refer to the understanding and manipulation of genes (DNA).

Concepts.definition: A laboratory procedure that involves the study of tissues, cells, and fluids using DNA/RNA analysis techniques for the identification of characteristics and abnormalities at the molecular level.

Property.preferredDefinition: Major protein component of chromatin.  Highly conserved basic proteins, originally classified into classes based on the relative amounts of arginine and lysine in each protein.  The various classes are now termed H1, H2A, H2B, H3, and H4.  In chromatin, they are found in an octamer, containing two each of H2A, H2B, H3, and H4, complexed with DNA in nucleosomes.  The histones in the octamer complex are also known as the core histones.  The H1 class of histones, termed the linker histones, is loosely associated with the nucleosome.:A set of genes coding for diverse proteins which, by virtue of their high degree of sequence similarity, are believed to have evolved from a single ancestral gene.

Concepts.definition: Major protein component of chromatin.  Highly conserved basic proteins, originally classified into classes based on the relative amounts of arginine and lysine in each protein.  The various classes are now termed H1, H2A, H2B, H3, and H4.  In chromatin, they are found in an octamer, containing two each of H2A, H2B, H3, and H4, complexed with DNA in nucleosomes.  The histones in the octamer complex are also known as the core histones.  The H1 class of histones, termed the linker histones, is loosely associated with the nucleosome.
A set of genes coding for diverse proteins which, by virtue of their high degree of sequence similarity, are believed to have evolved from a single ancestral gene.

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: A grouping of items based on some commonality or by user defined characteristics.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Linker Histone H1 interacts with DNA between nucleosome units in mediating chromatin compaction into higher order structures. Histones are basic nuclear proteins responsible for the nucleosome structure of eukaryotic chromatin. Repeating nucleosome units contain two molecules each of core Histones H2A, H2B, H3, and H4 that form an octamer complex around which approximately 146 base pairs of DNA is wrapped. (NCI)

Concepts.definition: Linker Histone H1 interacts with DNA between nucleosome units in mediating chromatin compaction into higher order structures. Histones are basic nuclear proteins responsible for the nucleosome structure of eukaryotic chromatin. Repeating nucleosome units contain two molecules each of core Histones H2A, H2B, H3, and H4 that form an octamer complex around which approximately 146 base pairs of DNA is wrapped. (NCI)

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Slightly lysine rich histone.  One of four histones assembled into a nucleosomal core octamer.  Various posttranslationally modified forms and variants exist.  Combines with histone H2B in a heterodimer; two H2A/H2B dimers are incorporated in the nucleosomal octamer.

Concepts.definition: Slightly lysine rich histone.  One of four histones assembled into a nucleosomal core octamer.  Various posttranslationally modified forms and variants exist.  Combines with histone H2B in a heterodimer; two H2A/H2B dimers are incorporated in the nucleosomal octamer.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Histone H2B is a core subunit of the eukaryotic nucleosome complex. Histones are basic nuclear proteins responsible for the nucleosome structure of chromatin. Repeating nucleosome units contain two molecules each of Histones H2A, H2B, H3, and H4 that form an octamer complex around which approximately 146 base pairs of DNA is wrapped. Linker Histone H1 interacts with DNA between nucleosome units in mediating chromatin compaction into higher order structures. (NCI)

Concepts.definition: Histone H2B is a core subunit of the eukaryotic nucleosome complex. Histones are basic nuclear proteins responsible for the nucleosome structure of chromatin. Repeating nucleosome units contain two molecules each of Histones H2A, H2B, H3, and H4 that form an octamer complex around which approximately 146 base pairs of DNA is wrapped. Linker Histone H1 interacts with DNA between nucleosome units in mediating chromatin compaction into higher order structures. (NCI)

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Arginine rich histone.  One of four histones assembled into a nucleosomal core octamer.  Various posttranslationally modified forms and variants exist.  Combines with histone H4 in a heterotetramer of composition (H3)2(H4)2; one tetramer is incorporated in the nucleosomal octamer.

Concepts.definition: Histone H3 is a core subunit of the eukaryotic nucleosome complex. Histones are basic nuclear proteins responsible for the nucleosome structure of chromatin. Repeating nucleosome units contain two molecules each of Histones H2A, H2B, H3, and H4 that form an octamer complex around which approximately 146 base pairs of DNA is wrapped. Linker Histone H1 interacts with DNA between nucleosome units in mediating chromatin compaction into higher order structures. (NCI)

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Histone H4 is a core subunit of the eukaryotic nucleosome complex. Histones are basic nuclear proteins responsible for the nucleosome structure of chromatin. Repeating nucleosome units contain two molecules each of Histones H2A, H2B, H3, and H4 that form an octamer complex around which approximately 146 base pairs of DNA is wrapped. The nucleosome interacts with DNA between nucleosome units in mediating chromatin compaction into higher order structures.

Concepts.definition: Histone H4 (103 aa, ~11 kDa) is encoded by the human H4C1, H4C2, H4C3, H4C4, H4C5, H4C6, H4C6, H4C8, H4C9, H4C11, H4C12, H4C13, H4C14, H4C15, H4-16 genes. This protein plays a role in nucleating the formation of high order chromatin structures as a part of nucleosomes.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Not known, not observed, not recorded, or refused.

Concepts.definition: Not known, observed, recorded; or reported as unknown by the data contributor.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Abnormalities that occur in human cells and tissues and models of human cancer.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: Category; used informally to mean a class of things.

Concepts.definition: A grouping of items based on some commonality or by user defined characteristics.
